repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - First, Second and Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation and Second and Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Technical Assistance Programs

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program (FRDP 1)had the following ratings:
            unsatisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impact, satisfactory Bank
            performance, and unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The
            Second Fiscal Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP
            11) had the following ratings: unsatisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance The First Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP I), and
            unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP 111) had the
            following ratings: highly unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, negligible institutional development impact,
            highly unsatisfactory Bank performance, and highly
            unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Second Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program TA (FRDP 11TA) had
            the following ratings: moderately satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, satisfactory Bank performance, and satisfactory
            Borrower performance. The Third Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program TA (FRDP 111TA) had the following
            ratings: unsatisfactory outcome, unevaluable sustainability,
            modest institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and satisfactory Borrower performance. The
            experience in these projects highlights the following
            lessons: (a) incentives within the Bank can motivate unwise
            lending; (b) the region's macroeconomic assessments
            need to have greater realism and consistency; (c)
            policy-based lending in an unstable macroeconomic
            environment is unwise; (d) in promoting reform, the Bank
            needs to take account of the incentives that a program
            creates; and (e) the Bank should structure lending to Malawi
            with more earmarked, targeted aid, and tighter fiduciary controls.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Third Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, having attained only modest
            institutional development impacts. While the risks of
            significant lack of follow-through were previously
            described, it would not have been sufficient for this nature
            of operation, where the window of opportunity is small, and
            the benefits lie in maintaining the general direction of
            reform, rather than taking quantum steps. This said, it is
            important that credit amounts be maintained at levels which
            are commensurate with the measures being undertaken. The
            originally proposed two tranche operation might have been
            back-loaded, given the weight attached to conditions for
            second tranche release. However, the increase in the size of
            the first tranche relative to the amount agreed with the
            government, sends wrong signals to the borrower, and reduces
            the credibility of our follow-up operations. In addition, as
            mentioned above, the funds were not used to capitalize the
            National Food Reserve Agency (NFRA), which had been the
            motivation for topping-up. Two areas of the credit represent
            major successes where the Malawian experience may be
            replicable for other countries. The approach of setting up
            an independent revenue authority with a fixed percentage of
            collections allocation for its operations, seems to have
            worked well in providing the motivation which the agency
            needed. Secondly, Malawi's success in privatizing both
            the commercial banks, and petroleum import sector in a small
            market where there is only room for a limited number of
            enterprises, suggests that with setting appropriate rules,
            these can still result in significant efficiency gains. This
            operation underlines the importance of having good analytic
            work as a basis for Bank lending and support to governments,
            analytic work which needs to be designed strategically, to
            avoid the risk of designing conditionality in the areas
            where solid analytical underpinnings already exist, instead
            of focusing on areas which are critical to the overall
            success of the Government's reform program.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - The Third Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Project and the Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program Technical Assistance
            Project (FRDP III)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Project and the Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program Technical Assistance
            Project are made in support of policy reforms designed to
            accelerate economic growth and reduce poverty; and to help
            deepen structural reforms launched in 1995 to improve public
            sector management, promote private sector growth, and
            strengthen the social safety net; and to help Malawi
            implement policy reforms, especially in the area of
            financial management, supported by the Credit. The Credit
            will also assist the Government in maintaining macroeconomic
            stability by meeting financing requirements (gap) in the
            balance of payments. In the fiscal accounts, the Credit will
            enable the Government to maintain an overall non-interest
            expenditure level at about 24 percent of GDP. This will
            allow the Government to protect outlays in key social
            sectors, while reducing domestic borrowing, thereby helping
            to reduce inflation and interest rates.
